{"step_by_step_thinking": "The patient's symptoms of abdominal pain, vomiting, and obstipation, along with the physical examination findings of a distended abdomen with diffuse tenderness and high-pitched bowel sounds, suggest a bowel obstruction. The x-ray findings of a dilated bowel, multiple air-fluid levels, and branching radiolucencies in the right infra-diaphragmatic region are indicative of pneumobilia, which is air in the biliary tree. This is most commonly caused by a gallstone that has migrated into the bowel and caused an obstruction, a condition known as gallstone ileus. Therefore, the most likely cause of this patient's condition is not a perforation of the duodenal wall, inflammation of the gallbladder wall, or torsion of the large intestine, but rather an obstruction of the common bile duct due to a gallstone.", "answer_choice": "C. Obstruction of the common bile duct"}
